content.body: iwan.aucamp: there have been a few attempts, see the issues; none has really made it to the point where it would seem like a clear improvement, at least to me

content.body: A clear improvement as compared to not having one, or as compared to the IETF grammar?
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: A clear improvement as compared to not having one, or as compared to the IETF grammar?

content.body: It seems to me that if the intent is indeed to obsolete RFC 3986 then a providing a grammar would be an essential part of it.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: It seems to me that if the intent is indeed to obsolete RFC 3986 then a providing a grammar would be an essential part of it.

content.body: I see for example mention in the one issue that it would be simple, but if it  would be, why not just make it?
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: I see for example mention in the one issue that it would be simple, but if it  would be, why not just make it?

content.body: Not all assertions on the internet happen to be true. ðŸ™‚ Likewise, you might find that not everyone is as convinced about the merit of grammars.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Not all assertions on the internet happen to be true. ðŸ™‚ Likewise, you might find that not everyone is as convinced about the merit of grammars.

content.body: Okay, but say I want to incorporate it into another format, like Turtle?
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Okay, but say I want to incorporate it into another format, like Turtle?

content.body: or into another grammar?

iwan.aucamp: in most cases you wouldn't want that grammar to fall over the moment this grammar is extended in some way, so usually you'd have a somewhat broader field and then define processing requirements around it

content.body:
> <@krosylight:mozilla.org> A webidl2.js update should not break wpt in a way that each test should be adjusted (idlharness is the only thing it should affect). Not sure that applies to all dependencies
